Blocking buffer is removed by washing with PBS/Tween and the microtiter plates are covered and stored at 4 (degree) C. until use. Test samples of biological fluid, i.e., a urine sediment sample (supra), are prepared as serial dilutions in PBS, pH 7.0 and 100 MU l of each dilution is added to a well of the coated microtiter plate containing the bound MBP.
Binding between the MBP and any bacterial murein, or fungal murein-like, analyte in the test sample is allowed to continue for 45 minutes to 1 hour at room temperature, and then unbound materials are removed by washing 4-6 times with PBS/Tween.
Bound murein, or murein-like, analyte is detected stepwise: first, by adding 100 MU l/well of a detect reagent HRP-lysozyme-conjugate (EXAMPLE 3, above) dissolved in PBS, pH 7 0 (slashed zero) The reaction between the detect reagent and the bound-analyte is allowed to continue at room temperature for 30-90 minutes and unbound detect reagent is next removed by washing with PBS/Tween, followed by PBS.
Second, the bound detect reagent is visualized by adding 100 MU l of a colorimetric substrate for HRP, i.e., a solution of ABTS (2,2'-azino-di(3-ethylbenzthiazoline sulfonic acid) at a concentration of 0.16 mg/ml in PBS, pH 6.0 and containing 0.0004% (freshly prepared) hydrogen peroxide.
Visible color development is allowed to continue for 10-60 minutes, and absorbance is quantified spectrophotometrically at 405 nm (i.e., in an ELISA plate reader).
Third, the results are quantified by comparing the absorbance recorded with the absorbance produced by measured amounts of murein ligand standards run in parallel, i.e., in other wells of the MBP-capture microtiter plate during the assay of the test substance.
The absorbance produced by the standards is used to construct a standard curve, and the absorbance value for the test sample may be compared with the standard curve to determine the bacterial-equivalents of a murein, or murein-like, ligand in the sample.
The results, may be used to set acceptable cut-off values of reactivity for "normal" in the assay, e.g., an "infection" may indicated if a value obtained with a test sample from an individual is more than one standard deviations greater than a mean background value recorded with a panel of sample from normal healthy individuals.
Individual cut-off values may also be indicated for different clinical grades (severity's) of infection.

EXAMPLE 8
Diagnostic Assay for Fungal Infections

The following example illustrates the instant diagnostic methods as used to rapidly identify a bacterial or a fungal infection; or, to rapidly differentiate between a bacterial and a fungal infection in a host in need thereof; or, to quantify the severity of a fungal infection in a patient in need thereof, e.g. a urinary tract infection.
Urinary Tract Infections:

Urinary tract infections (UTI) include urethritis (infection of the urethra), cystitis (bladder infection) and pyelonephritis (kidney infection.) Bacteria and fungi are common etiologic agents in UTI.
Most bacterial infections are E. coli, Klebsiella or Proteus and fungal infections are yeast of the genus Candida (e.g., C. albicans, C. kruzei, C. glabrata, C. tropicalis and the like) and fungi of the genus Torulopsis (e.g., T. glabrata) and Trichosporon (e.g., T. beigelii.) There are great differences in the assay sensitivity required to detect bacterial or fungal infection.
For instance, threshold for UTI for bacterial infection is considered to be greater than about 105 colony forming units (CFU), as contrasted with only about 1000 CFU/ml urine to confirm a yeast infection.
Most antibiotic treatment is initiated before, or without, identification of the etiologic agent because several days are usually required to culture the bacteria or fungi responsible.
Widespread use of antibiotics has favored emergence of antibiotic resistant bacteria and fungi, and the growing prevalence of resistant microbes (particularly in the clinical environment) has complicated treatment of patients.
Among patients with fever and pyuria unresponsive to antibiotics the mortality rate is presently greater than 30%.
In addition, several patient groups are at an increased risk of developing life-threatening ascending infections capable of developing into kidney and/or systemic infections: namely, immunocompromised patients (e.g., transplant, cancer patients, AIDS patients) including patients treated with immunosupppressive drugs (e.g., patients with autoimmune diseases such as IDDM, SLE, RA); indigent, elderly and diabetic patients; and, hospitalized patients (e.g., nosocomial infection, prostate disorders, pregnant women.) As a means for reducing costs, managed healthcare will eventually mandate early diagnosis and use of methods for distinguishing at an early stage between bacterial and fungal UTI infections.
Clinical Diagnostics Laboratorv Testing:

Current methods of plate culture and microscopic examination are too slow (i.e., days) to provide information useful in deciding treatment, and instead are used, (after the fact), to confirm bacterial, and/or fungal, infection.
Current microscopic wet mount and/or plate culture methods are used to identify yeast in urine sediments.
For detection by microscopic examination, more than 1000 colony forming units of yeast per milliliter of urine may be required; and, for detection by culture, 2 or more days may be required since yeast are relatively slow growing.
As a result, false-negative test results and uncertainty are common.
Alternative methods such as ELISA, calcofluor and PCR are expensive, slow, not easily automated, not pan-fungal reactive, often reactive with mammalian cell elements and bacteria, and have high background non-specific reactivity with non-fungal particulate matter (e.g., cotton lint).
Performing these assays also commonly requires specially trained personnel.
Existing techniques also do not commonly aid the physician to identify or determine a severity of infection or provide information useful in deciding whether to treat with an aggressive course of high-dose antibiotic therapy.
Current Limitations to Flow Cytometry Methods

Flow cytometry has limitations when used for automated counting of infectious microorganisms including: high background counting of non-microbial particles; the small numbers of microorganisms present (e.g., <1000 cells/ml yeast) necessitating long counting times at the lower limits of machine counting.
For a 10 ml urine sample, it is preferable to count about 7,000-10,000 cells to diagnose a yeast UTI, but using e.g. a urine sediment sample of 500 MU l, counting at 20 cells per second at a flow rate of 60 MU l/minute may require 6-7 minutes per sample to record this number of cells.
As a further complication for cytometric counting, it was discovered that bacteria and fungi in urine tend to aggregate and form into clumps, rafts and aggregates which may be commingled with mammalian cell debris in the samples (FIG. 2A.)

FIG. 2A shows a fluorescence photomicrograph of staining of yeast clusters and aggregates observed when Candida albicans was added to normal urine sediment and stained with F-NHS-catalytically disabled lysozyme.

Filamentous fungi also grow in chains or hyphae that are not conducive to counting by cytometric methods.
Due to these combined confounding properties, particle counting methods may often under-estimate the actual numbers of cells by more than 5-10 fold.
Similarly, culture methods may under-estimate the numbers of fungi by at least 2-3 fold because many yeast colonies originate from cell clusters (Perfect, 1991.)
The Instant Assay Methods: Summary Overview

Since biological samples from infected individuals contain bacterial and fungal aggregates, as well as, `confounding` and `interfering` substances (supra), i.e., murein binding compounds such as endogenous chitinases and lysozymes attempts were made to produce single cell fungal and bacterial suspensions by combinations of acid and/or base hydrolysis and protease treatment.

As detect compounds, F-NHS-labeled catalytically-disabled lysozyme (i.e., Preparation -1 supra) and F-NHS-lysozyme and were prepared according to EXAMPLE 1 and comparisons were made of their effectiveness for detection of alkaline and/or protease killed and denatured bacteria and fungi by flow cytometry.
Most pathogenic fungi contain chitin in their cell walls, septa and spores, both in hyphal and yeast forms.
Chitin is a BETA 1 --> 4 linked linear polymer of 2-deoxy-2-acetamidoglucose (N-acetyl glucosamine, GlcNAc.) Fungi do not contain bacterial murein proteoglycans and chitin is a poor substrate for lysozymes with hydrolysis of chitins proceeding at a much slower rate than mureins.
Similarly, bacteria do not contain chitin and are not reactive with chitinase.

Surprisingly, using fluorescence microscopy and Candida albicans as a test fungi, F-NHS-labeled catalytically-disabled lysozyme and F-NHS-lysozyme both stained yeast cells, and much more brightly than the staining that could be achieved using a chitin-specific binding protein, i.e., chitin glycosyl hydrolase-F-NHS conjugate.
Neither F-NHS-labeled conjugate stained mammalian or plant cells or their products.
Also surprisingly, under the conditions of use, staining of bacteria in urine sediments was not as easily detectable as staining of fungi, i.e., because of their size.
In other words, under the conditions of use in cytofluorimetric assays the method was able to selectively distinguish between the presence of bacteria and/or fungi in a test sample.
Fluorescence labeling of Candida by both the F-NHS-catalytically disabled lysozyme and the F-NHS-lysozyme depended upon the preparative method (supra) used to prepare a biological sample for analysis.
Fluorescence signal generation was markedly greater, i.e., as measured by fluorescence intensity in fluorescence cytoinetry, when a test Candida yeast in a urine sediment was subject to alkaline denaturation followed by N-acetylation, but not O-acetylation.
While not wishing to be tied to any particular mechanism of action, but by way of possible explanation, lysozyme binding specificity for yeast cells may require the presence of murein-like compounds and lysozymes may not effectively bind chitosans in a fungal cell wall with sufficient affinity to generate a signal in the assay.
Chitosan is present as a natural cell wall material in fungi, or as a possible result from deacetylation following alkaline treatment procedures (supra).
Chitosan may be converted to murein-like compounds by N-acetylation (supra.) In different experiments, the conditions suitable for N-acetylation, without destroying the killed and denatured yeast particles in urine sediments, were found to be treatments at a final dilution of about 1/20-1/40 acetic anhydride (i.e., 5-10 MU l for 200 MU l to 300 MU l total sample volume; about 1-10% acetic anhydride final concentration); using chemically pure acetic anhydride (e.g., distilled to remove acetic acid); and, in a saturated solution of NaHCO3 at pH 8.0 for 15-30 minutes at room temperature.
Using the combination of both alkaline hydrolysis and N-acetylation the killed and denatured yeast or bacterial particles in the treated urine sediment were fully reactive with the lysozyme F-NHS-conjugate (EXAMPLE 1, Preparation -1, supra).
In the absence of an alkaline treatment the signal was dramatically reduced.
Protease treatment did not increase the signal of a sample exposed to both treatments, but it did increase the signal of a sample with fungal aggregates and subject to only the alkaline treatment.
However, periodate oxidation (i.e., increasing the number of free sugar residues available for acetylation) followed by acetylation did increase signal strength in certain samples.

In comparative studies, killed and denatured fungi in alkaline- and N-acetylation-treated urine samples were as reactive with F-NHS-lysozyme as with the catalytically disabled lysozyme conjugate (Preparation -1, EXAMPLE 1, above.) The mechanism responsible is at present unknown.
The treatment method seems to produce killed and denatured fungal particles that contain substrates for catalytically active lysozyme conjugates, but, substrate turnover in the particles seems to be at a reduced rate, or turnover may not result in release of substantial free enzyme following the catalytic reaction.
First Illustrative Urine Sediment Sample Treatment Protocol:

One to ten milliliters of urine was centrifuged at 3000 rpm in a clinical centrifuge at room temperature (i.e., 22 (degree) C.) for 10 minutes.
The urine sediment was resuspended in 100 MU l 2N NaOH and subject to hydrolysis for about 15-30 minutes at 60 (degree) C. to kill bacteria and fungi; to hydrolyze and denature polypeptides and cell wall fragments; to expose murein- and murein-like-compounds in the particles; to alkylate cell surface charged residues involved in aggregation; and, to disaggregate bacterial or fungal rafts, aggregates and cell clumps without lysing cells.
Following alkaline treatment, the killed and denatured particulate suspension was brought to neutrality by adding 30 MU l of 6N HCl and setting it aside at room temperature for 10 minutes.
If aggregates, rafts or clumps of particles remained, the denatured cellular proteins in the particles were subject to an optional step of enzymatic hydrolysis, i.e., protease treatment with 0.25% trypsin for 30 minutes at 37 (degree) C. in a volume of about 100 MU l PBS, pH 7 0 (slashed zero) The chemical treatment alone was usually sufficient to hydrolyze bacterial and fungal intracellular adhesins; degrade potentially confusing polypeptides (e.g., endogenous chitinases, lysozymes and the like); degrade most potentially interfering substances (e.g., mammalian cells, bacterial cells, bacterial cell wall fragments, fungal cell wall fragments and the like); degrade fungal casts (e.g., releasing cells from hyphae); and release individual fungal cells from rafts, clumps, aggregates and the like.
To increase the reactivity of murein- and murein-like compounds with MBP, i.e. lysozyme, the killed and denatured particles were subject to N-acetylation by adding 100 MU l saturated NaHCO3, pH 8, followed by 5-10 MU l of pure (redistilled) acetic anhydride, i.e., final concentration in the assay of about 2-5% (v/v.) (N-acetylation was used to convert chitosan and other fungal compounds into more murein-like compounds reactive with MBP.) After 2-10 minutes at room temperature 100 MU l of PBS, pH 7.0 was added, followed by 100 MU l of PBS-5% BSA, pH 7.0, i.e., bringing the total volume to about 400-500 MU l. The particles were detected by adding 30-40 MU l of a solution of F-NHS-lysozyme (4-8 mg/ml), and by incubating for 15-30 minutes to effect binding of the MBP to the particles before microscopic examination in a fluorescence microscope or counting in a cytofluorimeter (i.e., FAXSCAN, Becton Dickinson Inc.) Cytofluorimetric counting was at a rate of about 5,000-9,000 killed and denatured particles per second and requiring about 2-30 seconds to count a total of 10,000-20,000 particles.

EXAMPLE 9
Rapid Detection of Antibiotic Sensitivity Culture in Antibiotic Followed by Cytofluorimetric Quantification

In a clinical setting it is often important to rapidly determine antibiotic sensitivity, e.g., in septicemic subjects, subjects with antibiotic resistant infections and subjects already undergoing treatment (i.e., to establish therapeutic efficacy).

The methods of EXAMPLE 8, above, were used to determine antibiotic sensitivity of bacteria.
To illustrate the technique, a single well-isolated colony forming unit of antibiotic-sensitive E. Coli was resuspended in nutrient broth to achieve a final concentration of about 108 bacteria per ml.
Different volumes of the bacterial suspension were then mixed into 20-30 ml of fresh human urine to achieve final concentrations of about 104 -107 /ml.
Without sedimenting the urine, 50-200 MU l aliquots of each different bacterial urine suspension were dispensed into each of the wells of a 24 well test microplate and bacterial growth medium, i.e., TSY broth, was added to each well to achieve a final total volume of about 1 ml to 1.5 ml. Assays were conducted in duplicate with 2 wells for a positive control (no antibiotic, just broth), 2 wells for a negative control (e.g., azide) and 2 wells for each different antibiotic concentration.
Antibiotics (e.g., ampicillin, tetracycline, erythromycin, cephalosporin, vacomycin, a augmentin and fluconazole -for yeasts) were added to each two of the two wells at an IC50 -IC90 concentration in a volume of about 10-50 MU l. Each test plate was then incubated under conditions, and for a time, effective to allow about 4 cell division cycles of the bacteria, i.e., at 37 (degree) C. for about 2-2.5 hrs. After incubation, the plates were centrifuged for a time and at a speed effective to sediment the bacteria, e.g., about 5 minutes at 2500-2800 rpm in an IEC bench top centrifuge.
The number of bacteria in each of the test wells was determined by adding an MBP-conjugate, i.e., lysozyme-FITC, incubating for about 40 minutes at 37 (degree) C. and quantifying stained bacteria in a cytofluorimeter according to the cytofluorimetric assay format disclosed in EXAMPLE 8, above.
In the presence of the three different concentrations of antibiotics, and in the negative control sample, a very low, but still detectable, bacterial signal was detected, while in the positive (growth) control a significant peak of bacterial fluorescence was recorded.
At the lower concentrations of certain antibiotics, e.g., ampicillin, a greater signal was recorded suggesting greater bacterial growth at the lower concentration of antibiotics and partial antibiotic-resistance of this particular laboratory strain of E. coli.
When the experiment was repeated with using a tetracycline-resistant strain of S. aureus, a significant peak of bacterial fluorescence was recorded in all three of the tetracycline wells and in the positive control wells, but not in the negative control (azide) well, or in wells containing higher concentrations of the other antibiotics.
Thus, the present assay allows detection of antibiotic sensitivity of an unknown bacteria in a patient sample after about 80 minutes of incubation, and about 3 hours of total time.

(b) repeat "step a" for each of the different antibiotics of interest, e.g., the 7 different antibiotics in the test kit; (c) dispense the negative control into one test well (e.g., azide) and place nutrient broth into another test well for a positive (growth) control; (d) dispense a test sample into each of the 23 wells; (e) dispense nutrient broth into each of the 23 different test wells; (f) incubate at a temperature and for an amount of time sufficient to effect about 2 to about 4 bacterial cell division cycles, e.g., about 2 hrs. at 37 (degree) C.; (g) collect the bacteria in each of the test wells, e.g., by centrifugation of the test strip for about 5 minutes at 2500-2800 rpm in a bench top IEC; (h) resuspend the collected bacteria into a smaller volume, e.g., about 500 MU l to about 800 MU l of nutrient broth; (i) add a volume of MBP-SGC conjugate effective to produce a signal in the positive control well, e.g., about 10 MU l to about 100 MU l of lysozyme-F-NHS according to EXAMPLE 2, above; (j) incubate at a temperature and for a time sufficient to effect a signal in the the positive control well, e.g., about 40 minutes at 37 (degree) C.; and, (k) determine the relative number of bacteria in the different samples, e.g., according to a cytofluorimetric assay of EXAMPLE 8, above.

A number of different variations on the assay format are envisaged.
It is possible to first quantify the signal produced by the bacteria in a sample, then culture in the presence of antibiotic, and re-quantify the signal.
If the signal has increased, the bacteria were antibiotic resistant; if the signal has not increased, the bacteria were sensitive.
In the latter case, the signal may be MBP-SGC binding to the bacteria (or yeast) or it may be a DNA stain, antibody-SGC or lectin-SGC.
One advantage of this assay format is that since it is only important to determine whether the signal increased, or remained unchanged, it is not necessary to carefully subtract any background (e.g., red cells, false positive results, bacterial aggregates, etc.) from the results at each time point.
Instead, it is only important that the machine baseline not drift extensively within the time frame of the assay, and this favors a relatively simple machine design since it is relatively routine to control for baseline drift.
This assay format may also prove amenable to machine automation involving the capture and release closed loop methods disclosed in EXAMPLE 10, below.
EXAMPLE 10
Rapid Concentration of Bacteria and Yeast from Complex Samples Using Solid-Phase Bacterial Capture and Release

Bacterial concentration from complex biological samples is often frustrated by the presence of interfering substance, e.g., mucus, cell debris, collagen and the like.
While filtration and centrifugation are commonly used, where contamination is an issue, i.e., of laboratory personnel or patient samples, it may be helpful useful to use an MBP-solid phase surface (EXAMPLE 4, above) as a specific extraction method to isolate and concentrate the bacteria (or yeast) from the biological sample.
Solid Phase Strips for Concentration and Extraction:

Preparation of illustrative MBP-solid phases appears in EXAMPLE 4 above.
Instead of filtration or centrifugation, such an MBP-solid phase may be used to capture, concentrate and isolate bacteria (or yeast) from a biological sample.
For instance, the solid phase strip may be immersed in a liquid biological sample, e.g., a dipstick suspended in a stirred waste water treatment tank to detect bacteria; or, a dipstick wiped along the surface of a solid biological sample, e.g., chicken or tables in a food processing line; or, a liquid biological sample may be flowed laterally across the solid phase-MBP surface, e.g., in a tubing coated with MBP.
Representative solid phase MBP capture surfaces are disclosed in EXAMPLE 4, above.
The latter surfaces are effective to capture bacteria and detection and signal generation may be achieved at the site of bacterial capture, e.g., by adding an MBP-SGC conjugate as a detect reagent, or adding a DNA dye as a detect reagent.
Closed Loop Capture and Concentration Systems:

Where contamination of laboratory personnel or patient samples is of concern, it may prove useful to inject a biological sample directly into an apparatus capable of making the necessary measurements, i.e., a closed loop machine system for detecting bacteria or yeast using MBP reagents.
For example, bacteria may be captured at a first site, e.g. a capture loop containing MBP bound to a tubing wall.
As fluid flows through the loop bacteria (or yeast) are concentrated, isolated and washed to remove interfering substances.
The bacteria may be detected directly in the capture loop, e.g., by flowing MBP-luciferase through the loop, washing, and then measuring the light signal emitted from within the loop following excitation.
Alternatively, it may prove useful to release the bacteria from the capture loop and conduct the detection and signal generation step at a second site, e.g., in a detect loop.
In such assay formats it may prove useful to link MBP to the surface of the capture loop-solid phase through a releasable linker, e.g., a disulfide reducible cross-linking agent (MBS, EXAMPLE 3, supra) or a light-releasable leash such as 6-(((4,4-difluoro-5-(2-thienyl)-4-bora-3a,4a-diaza-s-indacene-3-yl)stryryloxy)acetyl)aminohexanoic acid, succinimidyl ester (e.g., available as "D-1000" from Molecular Probes, Inc.).
When MBP, i.e., Preparation -1, EXAMPLE 1, was attached to polystyrene using D-1000, it was effective to capture, concentrate and isolate bacteria (or yeasts) on the surface and when illuminated with white light the bound MBP-bacteria conjugates were released.
The released MBP-bacteria were fully viable and determined by growing them in nutrient broth.
In one alternative use, capture and release may be used in a machine format to concentrate, isolate, detect and then release bacteria (or yeast) into a test assay for determining antibiotic sensitivity (i.e., as illustrated in greater detail in EXAMPLE below).
For example, one method for determining antibiotic sensitivity of a bacteria or yeast may involve the steps of: (a) capturing, concentrating and isolating the bacteria (or yeast) on an MBP-light releasable leash-solid phase; (b) releasing the MBP-bacteria conjugated from the solid phase using light illumination; (c) culturing the released MBP-bacteria, e.g., in a nutrient broth, in the presence and absence of antibiotic; and, (d) quantifying the number of the bacteria (or yeast) in the cultured samples by detecting a reagent capable of binding to the bacteria (or yeast), e.g., a DNA dye, specific antibody-SGC conjugate, an MBP-SGC and the like.
For example, cytofluorimetry according to EXAMPLE 8 may prove useful for quantifying the number of bacteria in the cultured samples.
EXAMPLE 11
MBP Dipstick Solid Phase Capture and Detect System for Rapid Quantification of Bacterial Content in a Biological Sample

As disclosed above in regards to urinary tract infections, it is often most helpful for a physician to be able to determine the relative number of bacteria or fungi in a patient sample, i.e., sometimes referred to as the "bacterial or fimgal load" or "bacterial or fungal burden".
Fluorimetric methods for quantifying the number of bacteria in a biological sample, e.g. as disclosed in EXAMPLE 8, above, require equipment that is often not available in a rural hospital, clinic or doctor's office.
Detection of a bacteria is possible using a mobile phase dipstick.
Quantification is also possible using MBP dipstick assay formats.
Size Exclusion Dipstick:

Dipstick assay formats may use size exclusion capillary mobility, i.e., bacteria and MBP-solid phase particles moving in a capillary fluid flow through a polymeric matrix unless their size is restricted by the matrix.
The assay may be designed so that: (a) the polymeric matrix allows particles having a cross-sectional diameter equal to that of a desired bacteria to pass through it with capillary fluid flow; (b) individual MBP-solid phase particles, e.g., MBP-polystyrene latex particles prepared according to EXAMPLE 4, above, are also able to pass through the matrix; and (c) bacteria containing about 3 to about 10 MBP-solid phase particles are no longer able to pass through the matrix, i.e., they are size restricted.
For example, in an assay where the polymeric matrix has a size exclusion limit of about 4-11 MU , a theoretical bacteria with a cross-sectional diameter of about 1 micron (1 MU ) will bind about 3 to 10 MBP-solid phase latex beads (1 MU diameter) and then become trapped and stop migrating with the capillary fluid and solute.
Examples of size exclusion polymeric matrices include cross-linked agaroses (e.g., Sepharose-CL, Pharmacia Upjohn Corp., Piscatawy, N.J.), cross-linked polyacrylamides (e.g., BioRad Laboratories, Inc., Oakland, Calif.), cross-linked celluloses, hydrogels and the like.

Dipstick components and assembly methods are known to those skilled in the art.
For example, in a rectangular, one-end-open, box-shaped dipstick design it may prove useful to suspend the subject polymeric matrix in a space between an upper member, a lower member, two side piece members and an end piece member; all of which comprise a liquid impervious barrier.
For components, e.g., the upper member may be composed of polyethylene, vinyl, Mylar, cellophane and the like; the lower, side and end piece members composed of a cardboard, solid bleached sulfite, polycarbonate, Lexan (tm) and the like.
A sample is introduced into the polymeric matrix through the open-end of the dipstick.
For purposes of loading sample and mixing it with MBP-solid phase reagents, or with sample preparation reagents (e.g., chemical or protease reagents according to EXAMPLE 8, above), it may be useful to include a bibulous pad within the open-end of the dipstick and in fluid-continuous-flow apposition with the polymeric matrix.
Examples of materials useful for this bibulous pad may include filter papers, non-woven synthetic polymers, glass fiber, fleeces and the like.
Illustrative methods for assembly of dipsticks are disclosed in U.S. Pat. Ser. No. 5,846,838 (Chandler et al.), U.S. Pat. No. 4,168,146 (Grubb et al.), U.S. Pat. No. 4,366,241 (Tom et al.), U.S. Pat. No. 5,780,308 (Ching et al.), U.S. Pat. No. 5,656,448 (Kang et al.), U.S. Pat. No. 5,580,735 (Malick et al.) all of which are incorporated, in their entirety, herein by reference for useful polymeric matrices, dipstick assembly, materials, adhesives, beads, test kit components, enzymes, substrates, and assay fornats.

In practice it may prove desirable to select the size of the polymeric matrix and the size of the particular beads to trap just a particular size of bacteria from out of a mixture of bacteria.
For example, the theoretical 1 MU bacteria above; or, the number of MBP-solid phase beads may be adjusted to allow detection of a particular number of bacteria in a biological sample.
The dipstick format may be used to quantify bacteria present in a biological sample, e.g., where MBP-beads are present in a slight excess over the number of bacteria in a sample, samples containing smaller numbers of bacteria will result in higher numbers of MBP-beads per bacteria than samples containing fewer MBP-beads, thus the distance migrated within a size exclusion dipstick will be related inversely to the number of bacteria.

MBP-beads may be present in a zone, e.g., at the immersible bibulous end of the dipstick, or they may be scattered through out the matrix of the dipstick so that bacteria moving in the capillary fluid flow progressively pick up more and more MBP-beads as they migrate, and so that larger numbers of bacteria will more greater distances within the matrix before becoming trapped.
Thus, the distance of movement within the polymeric matrix may be used as one indication of the relative number of bacteria present in a biological sample.

As will be appreciated by those skilled in the art, once the bacteria are trapped within the matrix of a dipstick a variety of reagents may be added to the dipstick, or trapped within the dipstick, for purposes of detecting the trapped bacteria.
For example, the developed dipstick containing trapped bacteria may be dipped into a solution of a dye that bind to DNA or bacterial cell wall materials, a lectin, an enzyme reactive with a bacterial products, an antibody-SGC conjugate, a fluorophore, or an MBP-SGC reagent such as disclosed in EXAMPLE 3.
In this context, it will be appreciated that substrates, enzyme co-factors and/or assay signal amplification systems may be incorporated within the polymeric matrix of the dipstick.
Mobile Phase Dipstick:

A dipstick 1 made up of a narrow "x-axis" dimension 2, e.g., about 5 to about 7 mm; a longer "y-axis" dimension 3, e.g., about 5 to about 10 cm; a dip-end 10; and a holder-end 20.
Dipstick 1 is coated from dip-end 10 to holder end 20 with a polymeric matrix effective to allow capillary movement of particles having a diameter of about 1 micron to about 20 microns in a fluid, e.g., 10 mM phosphate buffered 0.14M saline, pH 7.4. The polymeric matrix of dipstick 1 is optionally infiltrated with an indicator capable of detecting the activity of an enzyme SGC, e.g., by immersion of dipstick 1 in a substrate/dye solution such as disclosed supra for alkaline phosphatase-SGC or horse radish peroxidase-SGC.
The indicator is trapped within the matrix by freeze drying the indicator-loaded dipstick 1.

A mobile phase reagent zone 30 is prescribed on dipstick 1 from a point at dip-end 10 to a point about 2 cm from dip-end 10.
Using a micropipet, reagent zone 30 is loaded with mobile-phase MBP-SGC-solid phase particles, i.e., about 3 * 107 to about 1010 polystyrene latex beads having a diameter of about 1 MU and having bound MBP-SGC, e.g., prepared according to EXAMPLE 4, above.
In this particular illustration, an enzyme SGC.
The mobile-phase MBP-SGC-solid phase particles are trapped within the matrix by freeze-drying (lyophilizing) the indicator-loaded mobile-phase loaded dipstick 1.

In operation, dipstick 1 is immersed in a biological sample, (e.g., a diluted urine test sample to which a buffer has been added, or a urine sediment sample according to EXAMPLE 8, above), for a time, (e.g., about 2 to about 15 minutes), and under conditions effective to allow capillary movement to a point about 2/3 of the y-axis dimension 3.
In embodiments containing enzyme-substrate indicator trapped within the polymeric matrix of test dipstick 1 detection of the MBP-SGC solid phase particles bound to bacteria and thereby trapped within the polymeric matrix is accomplished by incubating, preferably under moist conditions, for a time effective to allow conversion of substrate into a visible product.
In embodiments where enzyme-substrate indicator is not trapped within the polymeric matrix of test dipstick 1, then, test dipstick 1 is removed from the urine sample and moisture is allowed to evaporate for about 2 to about 15 minutes, i.e., not to complete dryness.
The moist, but evaporated, dipstick 10 is immersed in a substrate solution.
The SGC-enzyme, e.g., HRP, above, catalyzes conversion of fluid substrate, e.g., ABTS, to and insoluble red reaction product, thereby revealing the location of the MBP-SGC solid phase within dipstick 10.
As disclosed above, the distance migrated by the MBP-SGC-solid phase within test dipstick 10 will be related to the number of bacteria in the biological sample, i.e., the fewer the number of bacteria, the more particles which will be bound by bacteria and unavailable for movement in the capillary fluid.
The fewer the number of bacteria, the fewer the number of MBP-SGC-particles bound and the more mobile the complexes will be within the martix of dipstick 10.
Tangential Flow Mobile Phase Dipstick:

A dipstick 4 made up of a narrow "x-axis" dimension 5, e.g., about 5 to about 7 mm; a longer "y-axis" dimension 6, e.g., about 5 to about 10 cm; a dip-end 11; and a holder-end 21.
Tangential flow dipstick 4 according to the invention, depends upon capillary fluid flow through a first polymeric matrix 7, i.e., along a "y-axis" dimension 6, as well as lateral diffusion-fluid flow, i.e., along an "x-axis" dimension 5, in this case, from first matrix 7 into a second polymeric matrix 8.
The pore size of matrix 7 is effective to allow capillary movement of particles having a diameter of about 1 micron to about 10 microns in a fluid thereby trapping bacteria having about 3 to about 10 bound MBP-SGC-solid phase particles.
The pore size of second matrix 8 is effective to allow fluid flow of particles having diameters in excess of 8 microns, i.e., bacteria having bound MBP-SGC-solid phase particles.

Dipstick 4 is coated along a channel 12 from dip-end 11 to holder end 21 with polymeric matrix 7.
For example, channel 12 located at a right edge 13 of dipstick 4 has a width of about 1 mm except at dip-end 11 where it spans the width of dipstick 4 and extends upward from dip-end 11 a distance of about 2 cm up along the y-axis 6 forming about a 2 cm high mobile phase reagent zone 31.
A fluid barrier zone 14, separates an uppermost portion 15 of reagent zone 31 from the remainder of the dipstick 4.
The remainder of dipstick 4, i.e., exclusive of reagent zone 31 and channel 12 is coated with second polymeric matrix 8.
Reagent zone 31 is loaded with mobile-phase MBP-SGC-beads, i.e., about 3 * 107 to about 1010 polystyrene latex beads having a diameter of about 1 MU and having bound MBP-SGC, (e.g., prepared according to EXAMPLE 4, above); in this particular illustration, an enzyme SGC.
Second polymeric matrix 8 is loaded with an enzyme-substrate indicator that is catalytically converted into a visible product through the action of the enzyme SGC bound to the MBP-SGC-beads.

In operation, bacteria flow by capillary action into and through matrix 7 along channel 12 until binding of MBP-SGC beads restrict their movement.
Thereafter, the bacteria-MBP-SGC bead complexes diffuse laterally into matrix 8 containing e.g., the enzyme substrate indicator.
Bacteria in a biological sample serve to concentrate the MBP-SGC-beads into a visible colored band or zone.
In the absence of bacteria the number of MBP-SGC-beads is too little and/or too diffuse In the latter illustration, as SGC-enzyme acts on substrate trapped in matrix 8 an insoluble visible product is formed.
As disclosed in regard to the "Mobile Phase Dipstick", above, the number of MBP-SGC particles applied to reagent zone 31 may be adjusted so that the distance which bacteria migrate along the dipstick is directly related to their number.
Zonal Mobile Phase Dipstick:

According to the methods illustrated above for mobile phase dipstick embodiments and tangential flow dipstick embodiments, the number of mobile phase MBP-solid phase capture beads may be adjusted to approximate a 3 to 10 fold excess over the number of bacteria to be detected in a biological sample.
Where the number of bacteria in the biological sample may vary widely, the number of mobile phase MBP-solid phase capture beads are varied according to about 3 to about 5 different "capture zones" proscribed at different locations along the y-axis of a dipstick, e.g., each containing a horizontal capture line having a width of about 0.2 mm to about 1 mm.
For example, a first capture zone may consist of one capture line, a second zone of two capture lines, a third of three and so on.
By having different numbers of capture lines within each different capture zones, a different number of MBP-SGC solid phase capture beads are provided, e.g., 106, then 2 * 106, 4 * 106, etc.
According to this particular illustrative embodiment, as bacteria in a biological sample progress by capillary flow along the y-axis of the subject dipstick they progressively encounter higher concentrations of capture beads, i.e., within the different capture zones, and when a sufficient number of beads are bound the motion of the bacteria is restricted by the polymeric matrix.
Continuous Gradient Mobile Phase Dipstick:

As a variation of the Zonal Mobile Phase Dipstick disclosed above, the subject "capture zones" may instead consist of a continuously increasing gradient of MBP-SGC solid phase beads applied along the y-axis of the subject dipstick, e.g., using a gradient maker and ink-jet type spray applicator.
As with the zonal mobile phase dipstick, as bacteria progress along the y-axis of the subject dipstick they encounter progressively greater numbers of capture beads.
Binding of MBP-beads to the bacteria will progressively increase the cross-sectional diameter until movement is restricted by the pore size of the matrix.
Again, distance migrated along the y-axis of the dipstick is inversely related to the number of bacteria in the biological sample.
Non-Mobile Phase Zonal Dipsticks:

Dipstick MBP assay formats are also envisaged in which MBP is fixed to the polymeric solid-phase matrix in capture zones having a width of about 0.2 mm to about 1 mm.
For example, the first capture zone may consist of one capture line, a second zone of two capture lines, a third of three and so on.
By having different numbers of capture lines within each different capture zones, a different amount of MBP solid phase capture reagent is provided, e.g., 106 molecules, then 2 * 106, 4 * 106, etc.
Test Kits:

Dipstick test kits commonly contain instructions; one or more dipstick assay devices; optional MBP-SGC detect reagent, e.g., in one or more squeeze bottles; optional substrate solution, i.e., for enzyme SGCs, e.g., in one or more squeeze bottles; an optional sample well, wash well and sample applicator; an optional bottle of wash fluid.
EXAMPLE 12
Methods for Determining Bacterial Genus and/or Species

It is possible to use the method of EXAMPLES 8 and 9, above, in combination with reagents for simultaneously determining the genus and species of bacteria (or yeast) present in a biological sample, i.e., referred to herein as "speciation reagents".
Representative examples of speciation reagents include genus and species specific bacteriophages, genus and species specific antibodies, lectins and the like as coupled to a SGC.
For example, according to the methods of EXAMPLE 8, a variety of two-color cytofluorimetric assay formats are envisaged where MBP-SGC-1 is used to detect and/or quantify bacteria (or yeast) and a speciation reagent coupled to SGC-2 is used to identify the genus or species of bacteria (or yeast) being counted.
Similarly, in a dipstick format a MBP may be used as a capture, a MBP-SGC-1 (e.g. HRP generating a red colored reaction product with ABTS) as a detect reagent and a speciation reagent-SGC-2 (e.g., alkaline phosphatase producing a blue reaction product); if bacteria are present a red band will appear, if the speciation reagent is reactive with the bacteria a dark rose, purple or dark blue color will result.
Multiplex, i.e., multiple channel, dipsticks are envisaged in which each different channel is contains, or is exposed to or dipped in, a different speciation reagent.
Using the red/blue example, above, a multiple lane dipstick might show red reaction product in all lanes except one, where a purple reaction product would indicate reaction with a specific speciation reagent-SGC-2.

claim.claim-text: A method for capturing, isolating and purifying a eubacteria or a fungus from a biological sample, wherein said biological sample is brought into contact with a solid phase comprising a catalytically inactive murein binding enzyme for a period of time and under conditions suitable for binding of the eubacteria or the fungus to the catalytically inactive murein binding enzyme thereby effecting said capture;

and wherein the eubacteria or fungus so bound is next either washed to remove exogenous materials and effect said isolation and purification, or alternatively, wherein said eubacteria or fungus so bound is first washed to effect said isolation and next treated in a manner effective to release said eubacteria or fungus thereby effecting said purification.

2. The method of claim 1, wherein said solid phase is selected from the group consisting of a polystyrene, a polycarbonate, a polyethylene, a polyacrylate, a polyvinyl, a polyvinylidene, a nylon, a cellulose, a nitrocellulose, a silicate glass, a polysylastic rubber and a magnetic particle.

3. The method of claim 2, wherein said solid phase is further selected from among the group of assay device surfaces consisting of a bead, a plate, a dipstick, a tube, a tubing, a filter paper, a microtiter well and a microtiter test strip.
4. The method of claim 1, wherein said catalytically inactive murein binding enzyme binds to said eubacteria or said fungus with a binding affinity of about 5 * 10-7 L/mol to about 5 * 10-9 L/mol.

5. The method of claim 1, wherein said catalytically inactive murein binding enzyme is selected from the group consisting of among an acetyl-muramoyl-D,L- alanyl amidase, a bacterial cell wall enzyme binding penicillin, an alanyl D,D- or D,L-endopeptidase, a D,D- or D,L-carboxypeptidase, a transglycosyl transferase, a peptidyl transferase, a muramoyl isomerase, a muramoyl transglycosylase, a murein autolysin, a murein hydrolase and a lysozyme.

6. The method of claim 1, wherein said catalytically inactive murein binding enzyme is selected from the group consisting of a mutant enzyme, a recombinant enzyme, and a chemically inactivated enzyme.
7. The method of claim 1, wherein said biological sample comprises a sample collected from a human, a domestic animal, a food, a drinking water, a waste water or an air source.

8. The method of claim 1, wherein said biological sample is selected from the group consisting of a sample of air, water, food, soil, mucus, sputum, urine, feces, sweat, tears, cerebrospinal fluid, lung lavage fluid, serum, plasma, peritoneal fluid, tumor ascitic fluid, cyst fluid, amnionic fluid, placental serum, semen and prostatic fluid.
